status_message:
I want to be absolutely clear: Today's reckless decision by President Trump is the height of cruelty and ignorance.  He has weakened our country, and we are all less safe for his cowardice.

Military leaders, decorated veterans, and members of Congress from both parties have rightly come together to condemn what is - by the administration's own admission - a cheap, cynical ploy to rally the darkest corners of Trump's base against yet another invented domestic enemy.
 
There is NO basis to Trump's claim that the service of Patriotic transgender people impacts our military readiness.  On the contrary, the President today has weakened our military and by doing so, diminished both our security and our standing in the world community.

Of course, we know that America's security (and America's global leadership) is not what this President cares about, nor has it ever been.  And so it is left to us, the PEOPLE of this country to care even more... to fill the void that he leaves every single day.

So please, today, tomorrow, and every day going forward - stand with your brothers and sisters of every race, religion, and gender that is a target of this administration's cruelty.   Support those organizations that are on the front lines against Trump's hate agenda.  Reach out to those in your community who everyday wake up fearing the worst.... and make sure they know that there is no tweet, no executive order, no act of  sanctioned aggression that will make you turn your back.

Our collective commitment to justice and equality is stronger than their fear and even their hate.  But we must NEVER waiver in our values.  We must NEVER hedge in our humanity.  And we must ALWAYS be unflinching in our commitment to those whose lives are at stake.
link_name: Trump announces ban on transgender people in U.S. military

I was proud to play a small role in this month's launch of the groundbreaking Firearm Violence Research Center.  

30,000 people die from gun violence in the United States - by homicides, suicides, and accidental shootings.  Based out of UC Davis, this innovative, data-driven center will use science to inform meaningful policy prescriptions... first in California, and then across the country.

Where the federal government has failed, California will continue to lead.  Too many lives depend on it.

status_message:
I‚Äôll be blunt: watching this video created by the NRA sent a chill down my spine ‚Äì one that was followed by a feeling of sadness and fear that I haven‚Äôt shaken a day later.  We live in an increasingly polarized country.  Between cable news, social media, and even the places we choose to live and work, it‚Äôs easier than ever to retreat into our ideological bubbles, attacking those who don't toe our ideological line.  Progressives do it.  Conservatives do it.  There are times I know I am guilty of this as well. 

But when I watch this video, I see something that crosses into an even more dangerous place: a piece of propaganda the goal of which is to teach the viewer that our fellow Americans are to be feared‚Ä¶ and even worse. How does this video advance debate?  How does it bring people together for common ideals?  How does it do anything but cast Americans as ‚Äúenemies‚Äù to be defeated in a cynical ploy to sell as many weapons as possible?
 
My history with the NRA is no secret.  I don‚Äôt hold them in high regard and I know they certainly aren't fans of mine.  And that‚Äôs fine ‚Äì we don‚Äôt need to work from the same values, and we probably never will. 

But today, I am asking the National Rifle Association of America - pleading with you in fact: Please, please, please remove this video.  There is no amount of gun sales that can offset the potential damage you may do with this.  Come after politicians.  Come after policy makers.  Come after ME.  But please do not villainize ordinary Americans.  Do not implicitly call for demonstrations of force against your fellow Americans in a country that is already reeling.  You are powerful.  People are listening to you.  And your message could lead to tragedy.
 
I‚Äôm willing to talk.  I‚Äôm willing to meet.  I‚Äôm willing to listen.  But please take down this video.
link_name: NRA Ad

Today Trump tweeted "Democrats purposely misstated Medicaid under new Senate bill - actually goes up."

It's important to know the facts. This is inaccurate. Here is the graph, provided by the CBO. Medicaid funding goes down. According to the CBO, the Senate bill has "a reduction of $772 billion in outlays for Medicaid." 

I can't stress enough how much of an impact this healthcare bill will have on our country. Do your research. Call your Senators. Get the facts and make your voice heard.

status_message:
Want to know why our beaches on the Monterey coast are disappearing? One word: CEMEX. CEMEX operates a sand mine on the coast that is stealing public resources for private profit and causing the rapid erosion of our beaches. This mine extracts the equivalent of a full dump-truck of sand every 26 mins. Yes, every 26 MINUTES. It is a relic of an era we rejected long ago. It must stop. 

Read my full statement here: http://ltg.ca.gov/news.2017.5.16_SandMine.html
link_name: CA regulators move toward closing Monterey Bay sand mine

status_message:
My mom was a waitress, a secretary, a paralegal ‚Äì she worked seven days a week and still managed to be there for me and my sister 24/7.

Somehow, even while raising two kids on her own, she opened her home to foster children and dedicated her life to helping those in need. Her motto was "don't explain, don't complain."

I still don't know how she did it all, but I know that I wouldn't be anywhere near the person I am today if it weren't for her.

I was diagnosed with dyslexia as a kid, and when out of humiliation I was ready to give up on reading, give up on school ‚Äì my mom pushed me. She didn't let me use my dyslexia as a crutch. She didn't let me use it as a reason to fail. I'm grateful every single day for that.

Moms have a way of doing everything and being everything to their families. My wife, Jennifer Siebel Newsom, amazes me every single day for just that reason ‚Äì and for the example she sets for our four kids. Thank you to all the moms out there for everything you do every day.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Russian interference in our election is a direct threat to our democracy. This should not be taken lightly. I'm hearing from lots of CA folks who want to know what they can do today to make a difference. 

Here are a few action items you can do TODAY:
1. Call your representatives and senators. Dial the Capitol switchboard, ask for your Rep, and tell them to support an independent investigation: 202-224-3121

2. Tweet at your elected officials (seriously, it makes a difference). List of Twitter handles for congressional members here: https://twitter.com/cspan/lists/members-of-congress/members

3. The House is in recess right now, which means many representatives are back here in CA hosting town halls. Find the closest one and go participate. Ask what they're going to do to hold Trump accountable for his campaign's ties with Russia. Search for your Rep's next town hall online, or see if it's listed here: https://townhallproject.com/

Things happen when we relentlessly speak out together for what's right. We've got to do that now.
link_name: List members

status_message:
I have 4 kids. No emotion in the world matches the fear of losing a child. Thank you, Jimmy Kimmel for being so honest and vulnerable in sharing this story and reminding us all of something that should never be ignored, taken lightly, pushed aside or forgotten: your ability to receive proper healthcare should never be based on how much money you make. 

‚ÄúWe were brought up to believe that we live in the greatest country in the world, but until a few years ago, millions and millions of us had no access to health insurance at all. Before 2014, if you were born with congenital heart disease like my son was, there was a good chance you‚Äôd never be able to get health insurance because you had a pre-existing condition. You were born with a pre-existing condition. And if your parents didn‚Äôt have medical insurance, you might not live long enough to even get denied because of a pre-existing condition.

If your baby is going to die, and it doesn‚Äôt have to, it shouldn‚Äôt matter how much money you make. I think that‚Äôs something that, whether you‚Äôre a Republican or a Democrat or something else, we all agree on that, right?‚Äù

This isn‚Äôt football. There are no teams. We are the team, it‚Äôs the United States. Don‚Äôt let their partisan squabbles divide us on something every decent person wants.‚Äù
link_name: Jimmy Kimmel Shares an Emotional Story of His Son's Heart Disease

status_message:
This is a literal life or death vote. The difference between a life saving procedure and not being able to afford it. Trump doesn't even know what his bill contains. 

I know all of this is frustrating, upsetting, tiring, and angering. But, I can guarantee you this: California will do everything in its power to stop Trump from stripping away people's care. We believe that everyone should have access to proper healthcare. And by access, I don't mean that the plan exists but you cannot afford to purchase it (lookin' at you, Speaker Paul Ryan). I mean being able to go to the doctor when you have strep throat. Or, have regular exams so you catch cancer before it spreads through your body. Or, not having to spend your entire paycheck because you fell and broke your arm. Real. Healthcare.
link_name: Pushing for Vote on Health Care Bill, Trump Seems Unclear on Its Details

status_message:
Here are the numbers for the president‚Äôs first 100 days.

*488*: The number of false or misleading claims made by the president. That‚Äôs an average of 4.9 claims a day.

*10*: Number of days without a single false claim. (On six of those days, the president golfed at a Trump property.)

*4*: Number of days with 20 or more false claims. (Feb. 16, Feb. 28, March 20 and April 21.) He made 19 false claims on April 29, his 100th day, though we did not include his interview with ‚ÄúFace the Nation,‚Äù since that aired April 30.

status_message:
Hi everyone, Jennifer Siebel Newsom here. Today is #EqualPayDay which represents how far into this year women have to work to earn as much as men did LAST year.

The wage gap is real, and it's persistent. Women still make just 80 cents for every dollar paid to a man ‚Äì and the wage gap is even wider for many women of color. African American women are paid 63 cents for every dollar white men make, and Latinas, just 54 cents.

These numbers tell a sinister story: that as long as we accept unequal pay, we don't see women as whole people. I am not 80% of a person. Neither are you, or the women in your lives. But every day the wage gap persists, that's what we tell women. California is home to 12% of the country's women - more than any other state. How we treat women in California sends an important message across the country, and women in many industries still face discriminatory pay practices, are subject to unfair scheduling practices at their jobs, and are less able to build up assets to create a safety net for themselves and their families. We need to fight for equal pay and demand better for women across California and the nation!
link_name: See what your state is doing to close the gender pay gap

status_message:
It's #InternationalWomensDay. Standing for equality means standing for a woman's right to make her own health choices. Planned Parenthood provides basic health services to millions across our country who may not otherwise have access. To defund it would be a horrific mistake and would have a lasting impact on our communities. Here's an important read on what Paul Ryan is actually saying when he says he wants to "defund."

"The government does not cut a blank check to Planned Parenthood. The family planning provider is listed nowhere in the federal budget, and a law already prevents taxpayer dollars from being used to pay for abortions. Planned Parenthood is only reimbursed for the non-abortion health care services it provides to low-income women, including birth control, Pap smears, breast exams and STI tests, through Medicaid and the Title X family planning program."
link_name: What It Really Means To 'Defund' Planned Parenthood

Daniela was just 7 years-old when she came here. Now, after using her voice to speak up about how important immigrants are to our communities, she's set to be deported without a court hearing. Everyone deserves justice.

Here's her full statement: 
"I don‚Äôt understand why they don‚Äôt want me. I‚Äôm doing the best I can. I mean I can‚Äôt help that I was brought here but I don‚Äôt know anything else besides being here and I didn‚Äôt realize that until I was in a holding cell last night for 5 hours. I was brought here. I didn‚Äôt choose to be here. And when I was brought here, I had to learn a whole new country and leave behind the one that I did know. And I barely knew that one. I feel, I strongly feel that I belong here and I strongly feel that I should be given a chance to be here and do something good and work in this economy. There‚Äôs so much that I can bring to the table, so much, like I can even teach music, I‚Äôm an excellent trumpet player you can ask my mom about any of that.  I‚Äôm great with math, I speak Spanish. status_message:
The one thing that connects every single one of us, regardless of our station in life and our backgrounds is the desire to love and be loved. For that to be denied because you happen to love someone of the same sex is wrong.
 
This day 13 years ago, San Francisco made a move that was a first for our nation. It was a rebellious gesture at the time, gay marriage was illegal almost everywhere including the state of California, but one that was needed to keep our country moving forward.
 
During the month that marriage licenses were issued, we witnessed couples traveling from all over the United States and from other countries to be married. We were able to witness joy, excitement, longing, love and hope amongst so many couples that had waited far too long to experience one of the biggest days of their lives.
 
But February 12th, 2004 isn‚Äôt what lead us to where we are today. It was the millions of conversations that were held and won on this topic that changed it. It was the debates amongst colleagues and family members, different generations engaging with one another. These conversations are what changed our nation. It‚Äôs been an unbelievable journey to get to where we are today. But as we recognize this anniversary, we must also recognize the fight ahead of us. 

With a President that seems determined to lead our nation backward, it is more important now than ever that we stand together to defend equality. We must continue to fight back against the hateful rhetoric and actions of the Trump administration -- but we cannot do it alone. 

It will take each one of us, engaging with our friends, our neighbors, and our colleagues. Creating environments where everyone feels protected, connected, and respected. Calling our legislators. Writing letters to our leaders. Marching together. Protesting peacefully. By standing together, we will build a moral wall to defend the values and principles that make our nation so great. Together, we can defend equality, continue to push for progress, and move our country forward.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Hatred has no home on California‚Äôs public university campuses in any form, from vitriol to violence. We witnessed both extremes at UC Berkeley's campus last night, from the racism and misogyny of fly-by-night provocateur and white supremacist Milo Yiannopoulos, to the excessive response of a few protestors. Both create fear, neither embody freedom.

Freedom of speech lives in the fabric of UC Berkeley; Cal is everything Trump University is not. President Trump's asinine threat to pull funding from Cal showed zero awareness of the real-world implications of a President's words and actions. Stripping federal funds from UC would only create more innocent victims and more Trump carnage. 
 
President Trump is quick to attack American students, immigrants, women, the LGBT community, journalists, and our international allies but he is either too weak or too ignorant to stand up to white supremacists and others who spew hatred. That's why the President and his extremist acolytes like Yiannopoulos need to hear from the resistance, loudly and repeatedly. We must continue to step in and stand up to resist reckless rhetoric and actions in a peaceful and forceful manner.

status_message: Thank you Senator Susan Collins and Senator Lisa Murkowski for putting country before party & refusing to support Betsy DeVos as our Secretary of Education.

A quick breakdown of the facts: 

- A refugee is defined as ‚Äúsomeone who has been forced to flee his or her country because of persecution, war, or violence.‚Äù

-  51% of refugees are children. 1% of all refugees will ever be resettled. 

- 1 in every 113 people in the world is a refugee.

- In 2016 California accepted 7,909 refugees, the most of any other state. 

- Immigrants in general, and refugees in particular, are among the least statistically likely people in American society to commit crimes of any kind.

- The vetting process for each individual refugee involves: 8 government agencies, 6 security databases, 5 separate background checks, 4 biometric security checks, 3 in-person interviews, 2 interagency security checks running data against criminal, intelligence, and terrorism databases

- Though the Executive Order only lasts 120 days, during that time clearances expire. Many refugees have waited years to get a chance to come to the United States. Those that are stopped from boarding their planes during this time may have to restart the process and wait years again. For many of those, this was a once in a lifetime opportunity which now may expire.

- The Executive Order does address religion specifically. It includes a provision stating Christian refugees and other religious minorities will be prioritized. Trump specifically noted this provision while discussing the ban. 

Know the facts and fight back with them. Knowledge is power -- we cannot let ignorance govern our nation.
link_name: 9 questions about the global refugee crisis you were too embarrassed to ask

status_message: My thoughts on President Trump's inauguration and what it means for California.

Today is an important day. It is a day in which we recognize the power of our democracy and the importance of a peaceful transition of power. But it is also a day that we recognize it is time to get to work. Now is the time for us to step up, step in and come together to demand progress.  Now is the time for us to fight for what we believe, not with violence and fear, but with our ideas and values that have helped make this country so great already.  We can continue to move this country forward, but we must do so together, with compassion, understanding, and dogged determination.  I'll be live at 3pm PST, tune in to hear my thoughts.

Yes we can.
Yes we did.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: Reflecting tonight on all that has been accomplished in the last 8 years.  From marriage equality, to allowing access to affordable healthcare, to the longest streak of job growth in our history, we have come so far as a nation.  Despite the election of Donald Trump as our President-Elect, we must remain hopeful and determined to continue to push our country in the right direction: forward.  I strongly believe that California can, and will, continue to lead by example.  We will push back against any sign of misogyny, bigotry, or hate. We will stand against injustices, and fight for equality for everyone. Now is the time for EVERYONE to step up & step in. We can continue to push this country forward but it will take all of us, working together to affect real change.

For me, Proposition 64 was never about being able to smoke marijuana, it was about how the War on Drugs has unfairly targeted minorities and the economically disadvantaged. Billions of dollars that could be going into childcare and healthcare are being wasted on police overtime, buy-bust programs and incarceration. I'm proud to say that in California we are looking to put an end to that and bring about change.
link_name: The Reefer Revolution: Democratic Rising Star Gavin Newsom Explains Passing Prop 64 With the Music Industry's Help

status_message:
Our teachers are heroes every day. But this day, 4 years ago, the teachers at Sandy Hook elementary school were heroes in the face of death, protecting their students from a deadly gunman who stole the lives of 20 innocent students and 6 educators. Risking your life to save another is most often the role of a soldier, police officer, or someone who has elected to put themselves in the line of duty. But on December 14th, 2012, our teachers reacted to danger with bravery and compassion, protecting their students and shielding them from harm.

Kindergarten teacher Victoria Soto, just 27 years old, hid her students after the gunman entered the school and died trying to protect them.  

Janet Vollmer locked her Kindergarten classroom door, covered the windows, took her students into a corner of her classroom, and read them a story to keep them calm.

First-grade teacher Kristen Roig took her students into a bathroom, locked the door and told them to keep quiet. She spoke softly to them, telling them everything was going to be ok, so they wouldn't cry and be heard by the gunman.

Anne Marie Murphy, who worked with children with special needs, died shielding 6-year old Dylan Hockley from the bullets that killed them both.

Lauren Rousseau, a 30 year old substitute teacher at Sandy Hook, died doing what she loved the most: teaching. She was known for her love of family, children, and her friendliness and loyalty that was on display every day for her students.

These are just a few of the many courageous stories of the teachers at Sandy Hook Elementary on December 14th. I am forever thankful for these teachers, and all of our teachers across our nation, who work to better the lives of their students every single day.

MUST READ: What we know about Russia's influence over our election. 

‚ÄúThere shouldn‚Äôt be any doubt in anybody‚Äôs mind,‚Äù Adm. Michael S. Rogers, the director of the National Security Agency and commander of United States Cyber Command said at a post-election conference. ‚ÄúThis was not something that was done casually, this was not something that was done by chance, this was not a target that was selected purely arbitrarily,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThis was a conscious effort by a nation-state to attempt to achieve a specific effect.‚Äù
link_name: The Perfect Weapon: How Russian Cyberpower Invaded the U.S.

status_message:
Donald Trump has treated Russian interference in our election as a partisan issue. This is not about political parties. Foreign interference in our electoral process is a direct threat to our country and national security. 

Mr. Trump should be focused on preserving the integrity of our democracy. Instead, he has dismissed the CIA and its findings, and has taken the time to question the existence of climate change and tweet about which media networks he prefers. These are alarming signs of poor leadership and a man who is too focused on his own ego to look up and govern. 

I applaud the effort of bipartisanship that Senators John McCain, Lindsey Graham, Chuck Schumer and Jack Reed have displayed, recognizing the need to work together during this critical time. As they have said, "the stakes are too high for our country".

Two years ago, OneWest filed foreclosure papers on the Lakeland, Florida, home of Ossie Lofton, who had taken a reverse mortgage, a loan that supplies cash to elderly homeowners and doesn‚Äôt require monthly payments.

After confusion over insurance coverage, a OneWest subsidiary sent Lofton a bill for $423.30. She sent a check for $423. The bank sent another bill, for 30 cents. Lofton, 90, sent a check for 3 cents. In November 2014, the bank foreclosed.

In October, lawyers at the nonprofit Florida Rural Legal Services contested OneWest‚Äôs foreclosure and asked the Polk County Circuit Court for a jury trial.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know that they‚Äôre the worst, but I certainly think it‚Äôs criminal the way these servicers are treating elderly homeowners,‚Äù said Lynn Drysdale, an attorney representing Lofton.
link_name: Trump Treasury pick made millions after his bank foreclosed on homeowners

status_message:
As parents of 4 young children, Jen and I believe the value systems that we raise our kids with start at the very beginning. This election normalized misogyny, bigotry, and bullying in a scary and unacceptable way. With the recent rise in hate crimes and bullying in our schools, we believe we must take immediate action to help curb this growing trend. 

This morning, I met with students and school leaders at Burton High School to discuss their experiences and the actions needed to prevent this tide of divisive behavior from becoming normalized. Now, I am sending a letter to all 58 county superintendents of education, calling on them to act immediately. 

So join us in this. Talk with your teachers, children, and fellow students about ways that you can help create an inclusive environment in every classroom, so every child feels like they belong.
link_name: Gavin and Jen Newsom Discuss the Current Rise in Hate Crimes a...

status_message: I'll be live at 12:30pm with immigrant students to call on our UC, CSU and Community Colleges to safeguard and protect our students from President-Elect Trump's mass deportation plan. Tune in!

These ideas are beyond appalling and alarming, they are dangerous. If not an infringement of our Constitution, this would be at minimum a violation of our fundamental values as a nation.  We cannot let our country move backwards. I sincerely hope President-Elect Trump does not put a policy in place that would endanger people in our country, promote discrimination, and mirror mistakes of our past.

It's been a long week.  

We have witnessed a nation divided and wounded. People feel frustrated and misunderstood, fearful and left behind, and in many cases - heartbroken by our country‚Äôs choices.  

We have seen horrific examples of racism, misogyny, and hatred. Too many Americans are forced to wonder if they are still safe, still wanted, still valued, and still accepted in our country.

Let me be clear about what we are doing and will do here in California: we will be active and participatory, moving our state forward, while staying vigilant and standing strong for our values and against any attempts to move us backwards.

In California, we believe in inclusion. 

We are a cause and a mission. We represent progress and don't back down. Now more than ever, I am proud of this state, where we have crafted the future first, year after year. We must have a sense of resolve and purpose, because the nation needs us. 

With increased reports of abusive and hateful incidents in the past week, too many kids are living in fear. So I want to repeat what I said to all children at the convention this summer: 

To our children, I want you to know that when you hear people say that you and your family don‚Äôt matter, because of who you are, what you look like, or who you love, I want you to know one thing -- The people in this state, and all across the country, believe that you matter. We believe that you belong here. We need you here. We believe that you can be whoever you are, and become whatever you want to be. And we‚Äôre going to fight for you.

Because in California we don't just tolerate diversity; we celebrate it. We don‚Äôt wait around for other states to catch up; we demand progress and drive forward. 

There is a lot of work to be done here and across the nation. We are ready.
"The wall I speak of in the sign is figurative. [It‚Äôs] a wall of hate, racism, and xenophobia that if built in the years ahead, will be teared down by my son and his generation."
link_name: This Photo Of A 3-Year-Old Defying Donald Trump Is What We Need Now

status_message:
Right now we need to focus our efforts on bottom up politics. Progress and change is still happening on the local level. We have agency, a voice, and can help shape the future. Now more than ever I am proud of this state, where the future has happened here first, year after year, in so many categories.  

California will be active and participatory, we believe in engagement and sharing our voice. It was disappointing to tell my 7 year old daughter on Wednesday morning that Donald Trump was our President, but I believe that California is remarkably adaptable and resilient. I have all the confidence in the world we will survive this Presidency, and that California will thrive because of our values. 

You can wake up and feel defeated, or wake up and have a sense of resolve and purpose. We can't wait around for others to do the work, we pushed forward on marriage equality, smart gun laws, and legalization of marijuana. Our job is to prove that things can be done, not just assert that. As many have said before me, we are many parts, but one body, bound together, so we can't walk away now. Now more than ever the country needs California.

‚ÄúHonor to the soldier and sailor everywhere, who bravely bears his country's cause. Honor, also, to the citizen who cares for his brother in the field and serves, as he best can, the same cause.‚Äù  ‚Äî Abraham Lincoln #VeteransDay

status_message:
Yesterday proved that California is a cause and a mission -- leading the country forward with inclusivity and innovation. 

We represent progress and don't back down on tough issues. We believe that inclusive societies are adaptable societies. We believe that adaptability and flexibility are what will allow us not just to survive the 21st century, but to thrive.

California has long understood that if we can practice the politics of inclusion, if we can try to build bridges and bring people together, we have unlimited potential. Let's celebrate that work and continue to push our country forward.

status_message: I'll be going live on facebook at 3pm to talk about Prop 63, 64 and the progress CA made last night. Make sure to tune in!

This morning, while I am frustrated by the choice of our next President, what I can say without any doubt is that I have never been more proud to be a Californian. We have voted for progress and opportunity for everyone, up and down the ballot. 

We have worked hard and I am so proud to say that Prop 63 and 64 have become the law of the land. And it is thanks to all of you.

These two causes were never about weapons or weed. 

They were about the health and safety of real Californians, saving countless lives ended by gun violence and shattered by unjust marijuana arrests. And they couldn't have happened without Californians coming together in common cause.

A lot of people thought we were a special kind of crazy to take on the NRA and the DEA in the same election. But here's the thing: Californians don't back down from the difficult. We see the invisible, invent the intangible and achieve the impossible.

We believe in equality and we believe in justice.  No matter how you look, where you live, what language you speak, or who you love.

California is blazing a different path - uniting voters around bottom-up reform WITHOUT tearing others down. And now more than ever, it is so important to continue that work. So, thank you all.

Make sure to take time today to use your voice and vote. This election is one of the most important of our lifetime, and we can't afford to sit it out. As for us we will be voting for candidates and propositions down the ballot that represent unity, and progress. Oh, and we're with her!  #Yeson63 #Yeson64

status_message:
‚ÄúMrs Clinton is a self-confessed incrementalist. She believes in the power of small changes compounded over time to bring about larger ones. An inability to sound as if she is offering an overnight transformation is one of the things that makes her a bad campaigner‚Ä¶
To hope that any good can come from Mr Trump‚Äôs wrecking job reflects a narcissistic belief that compromise in politics is a dirty word and a foolhardy confidence that, after a spell of chaos and demolition, you can magically unite the nation and fix what is wrong‚Ä¶
Herding bills through Congress to the point of signing requires a tolerance for patient negotiating and a command of sleep-inducing detail. Though it has been hard to hear above the demand to ‚Äúlock her up‚Äù, Mrs Clinton has campaigned for an open, optimistic country. She can take heart from the fact that, outside Washington, there is more bipartisanship and problem-solving than most Americans realise, and from the fact that popular pessimism has far overshot reality. Around 80% of Trump supporters say that, for people like them, America is worse than it was 50 years ago. That is false: half a century ago 6m households lacked a flushing lavatory. It is also a most un-American way to see the world. The time is ripe for a rebound.‚Äù

So much is at stake this election. One thing we should be able to come together around is ending the gun violence epidemic that has come to exist in America. 

Too many lives have been ruined by gun violence for us to passively wait for change. I'm sick and tired of the NRA blocking important legislation, and elected officials allowing their special interests to dominate our legislative bodies. 

Change is coming, and it's coming from the bottom up. Local politics matters, and we are proving that here in California. It's time to stand up to the NRA and let them know that they can't buy their way into our laws any more. Share this video, spread the word, and vote Yes on Prop 63 to help reduce gun violence!

Thank you JAY Z for your strong voice for social justice & co-creating this new Yes on 64 - The Adult Use of Marijuana Act - Prop 64 video. 

Today, marijuana is easily accessible, the black market is thriving and criminalization is disproportionately falling on communities of color, ruining thousands of young lives and wasting tens of millions of taxpayer dollars annually. Even President Obama has said that moderate use of marijuana is no more harmful than alcohol for otherwise healthy adults.

By legalizing marijuana use, we can regulate marijuana use. We can reduce consumption just like we‚Äôve done with tobacco. We can keep it out of the hands of minors with the strictest child safeguards in the nation and unprecedented new funding for youth education, prevention and treatment programs. 

We can help put an end to this failed war on drugs. We can do that, or we can stick with the failed status quo for another four years. I think Californians can do better.
link_name: Jay Z - The War on Drugs

status_message:
Thank you Santa Barbara Independent for supporting gun violence prevention and endorsing Prop 63! #YesOn63 

"We firmly believe in the Second Amendment and the right to bear arms. The Second Amendment doesn‚Äôt say anything, however, about the unrestricted right to buy firearms capable of shooting 120 rounds a minute or ammunition clips capable of holding off a small militia. California already requires background checks for people buying guns; Prop. 63, written by Lt. Governor Gavin Newsom, will require the same for people buying ammo. It also bans outright the sale of large-capacity ammunition clips ‚Äã‚Äî ‚Äãthe clips that allowed the tragedies at Sandy Hook, Columbine, San Bernardino, and so many more. And when a state with 39 million people makes a bold, powerful political statement like Prop. 63, a strong message is sent to other states where the elected officials might not be nearly so bold or powerful when it comes to gun violence."
link_name: 2016 Election Endorsements, Part One

status_message:
Bill Maher is an agitator, in the best sense of the word.

Bill pushes boundaries, not merely to shock, offend, and provoke (though he most certainly does shock, offend, and provoke), but to make us think, to stretch our brains, expand our horizons, and force anyone with intellectual honesty to ponder new perspectives. He doesn‚Äôt provoke us merely for the sake of provocation; he agitates because he understands that we have agency‚Äîthe responsibility and the ability to create change.

He informs and he entertains. He makes us laugh, scream, cuss, spit out our drink, and sometimes throw things at the TV. Bill tackles complex issues, while never missing a chance to highlight the abundant absurdities of our current debates. And isn‚Äôt that the challenge these days? To find creative ways to get busy people to pay attention to important topics, in a world teeming with distractions, constantly tempting them to click elsewhere and chase the shiny object?

For decades, conventional wisdom held that any show touching on public affairs must choose between two wholly distinct and tightly circumscribed paths: either intelligent, informative, and substantive, OR funny, opinionated, and entertaining‚Äîand never the twain shall meet. Bill exposed this as a false choice, for he is all of the above and then some. 

The older I get, and the more time I spend in politics, the more I appreciate something Bill possesses in abundance: authenticity. He has a truly unique set of opinions and issues he cares about, proving that there‚Äôs no possibility that he‚Äôs following any semblance of a crowd. He‚Äôs not bowing to sponsors, or ratings, or anything other than what he believes. He‚Äôs been nominated for thirty-nine Emmys, penned five bestselling books, and still performs stand-up across the country. But you get the sense that he‚Äôd be doing exactly the same thing even if no one was watching, reading, or paying him.

Sometimes he gets angry, but anyone who doesn‚Äôt sometimes get angry these days just isn‚Äôt paying attention. Sometimes he‚Äôs called a cynic, but I‚Äôd argue that he‚Äôs anything but. In fact, I consider him an idealist, because it‚Äôs clear that he cares passionately about people and animals. The reason it‚Äôs so compelling to watch him inveigh against all things unjust, inaccurate, illogical, and hypocritical is because he actually gives a shit. He‚Äôs the real deal.

Bill has never been afraid to use his platform to speak his own brand of cold, hard truths, even at the risk of his own career. When his network show was cancelled, he didn‚Äôt come groveling, hat in hand, with a kinder, gentler milquetoast appeal to a broader audience. Instead, he found a venue which allowed him to take his smart, frank, and brave approach to TV even further.

His show is based on the radical idea that if you really believe in something you should be willing to engage in a thoughtful, intelligent, extended discussion‚Äîeven an argument‚Äîabout those beliefs. That‚Äôs why he doesn‚Äôt surround himself with like-minded sycophants; he‚Äôd rather be around sharp minds who challenge him. He‚Äôs more interested in debating an intelligent, articulate opponent than in knocking down an obtuse straw man.
I‚Äôm a politician, so you won‚Äôt be shocked by this bit of truth-telling: sometimes guests like to appear on shows that allow them to lazily pontificate, without fear of being challenged or questioned. Bill‚Äôs show ain‚Äôt that place.

As a frequent guest on Bill‚Äôs show, I can tell you it‚Äôs not easy to sit on that panel with him. It‚Äôs the sort of challenge that people in public service should submit to more often‚Äîno free passes, no canned talking points‚Äîjust a real, honest‚Äîsometimes even a little vulgar‚Äîcage match of ideas. Guests can‚Äôt afford to be unprepared or inattentive, and Bill has zero tolerance for BS.

One of the keys to Bill‚Äôs success is that he listens, really listens to his guests. For a short time I hosted a public-affairs talk show of my own (a little-known fact, thanks to ratings that rivaled those of late-night C-Span reruns), where I learned just how hard it is to listen to a guest while trying to think of what to say next. Bill listens when others are speaking, a quality entirely too rare in today‚Äôs politics, and he‚Äôs more than willing to engage on a new piece of evidence, or follow a guest‚Äôs novel line of logic. His ability to deftly shift gears and explore fresh angles is what makes his show not just consistently compelling, but actually meaningful.

Like anyone who truly exemplifies the value of the First Amendment, and the need to protect it, Bill also pisses the hell out of a lot of people, including me. I disagree with him constantly, about all sorts of things, but, whether as a guest or a viewer, I never come away from his show without learning something new and appreciating the depth of the discussion.

Bill Maher is an envelope-pushing, hyper-intelligent, foul-mouthed, straight-talking, dope-smoking, hilarious, annoying, courageous, first-amendment hero. And he is eminently deserving of PEN Center USA‚Äôs esteemed First Amendment Award. Congrats!

There is far too much at stake this election to sit this one out. We must make our voices heard on November 8th.

status_message: I'll be going live on Facebook tomorrow to answer your questions about Propositions 63 and 64 on the CA  November ballot! What would you like for me to discuss? Comment below and make sure to tune in at 1:30pm tomorrow!

Woke up this morning to see that the shooter at Cascade Mall was obtained by the police. There are a lot of details we still don't know about the horrific shooting Friday night, when a man with a gun murdered five people in a mall outside of Seattle. But what we have learned is that 5 innocent people were shot to death, including a 16-year-old girl who had survived cancer, but not this trip to the mall. That's not the way the world should be.

In the time since this mass shooting, we have learned about yet another unthinkable shooting in Baltimore in which a toddler was shot, among seven other people, and across the U.S. other shootings and killings have occurred that won't even make the headlines.

There's nothing I can say now that hasn't been said before ‚Äì shooting after shooting, death after death. Frankly, I'm sick and tired of having to say it: No one should have to live in fear that the next time they walk into a mall, a movie theater, a school or a church, they will be shot and killed by a person who should never have had a gun in the first place. 

Yet already, far too soon, the headlines are beginning to fade. I have heard people describe the horror that unfolded that night as having ended the lives of "only five people." They are discussing this mass shooting like it's some kind of a small event, unworthy of our attention or the news. Well, I am not having that.

The bottom line is this: If we don't take meaningful action to end gun violence, if we let the NRA and cowardly politicians dictate the rules, more people will die. More parents will have to bury their children because we didn't have the courage to stand up and do something. More lives will continue to be turned upside down, and the media and our country will continue to become numb to it all. We can't let any of this happen.

My heart goes out to the families and loved ones of the victims and those who were in the mall ‚Äì I cannot begin to imagine the horror. You've got my word that I will do everything I can to pass reforms to stop the next tragedy and save lives. #enough #cascademallshooting

status_message: "A close examination by Newsweek of the Trump Organization, including confidential interviews with business executives and some of its international partners, reveals an enterprise with deep ties to global financiers, foreign politicians and even criminals, although there is no evidence the Trump Organization has engaged in any illegal activities. It also reveals a web of contractual entanglements that could not be just canceled. If Trump moves into the White House and his family continues to receive any benefit from the company, during or even after his presidency, almost every foreign policy decision he makes will raise serious conflicts of interest and ethical quagmires."

status_message:
15 years ago, lives were forever changed by terror and loss. Children watched as buildings crashed to the ground. Friends looked on as their colleagues disappeared from this earth forever. Families waited at home, praying their loved ones would return from work that day. 

Today, as we remember and honor those who we lost and risked their lives for our safety, I hope we can also remember how our communities came together to provide care and support for those suffering. We put aside our differences and recognized that, as many have said before me, what brings us together is stronger than what divides us. I hope we can all take a moment to remember that when we unite, we are stronger together.

status_message:
Donald Trump's speech last night was a disgrace to everything that California and our nation has accomplished with immigration reform. 

His trip to Mexico was nothing more than a hasty melodramatic photo op to attempt to win the hearts of Latinos across our nation. That failed attempt was followed by a speech condemning any form of amnesty and claiming that our current President hasn't done anything to fix it (he has actually deported more illegal immigrants than any other President). His speech laid out policies that will do nothing but bring our country backwards and produce more racism and fear.  

Immigration reform and amnesty is a bipartisan issue. President Reagan signed a law that gave amnesty to millions of illegal immigrants. President George H.W. Bush referred to immigrants as our neighbors, noting that we needed to work together to solve the problem, not put up a fence. In fact, even Donald Trump's "friend" Rudy Giuliani was a champion of amnesty and, as Mayor of New York, supported policies that protected illegal immigrants. 

This does not have to be such an intensely divisive topic that tears our parties apart. Last night Donald Trump showed once again that the stakes are high in this election. We cannot let a fear mongering, racist, hateful human being who proposes half baked policies and consistently flip flops on key issues be our President.

Donald Trump: "We didn't discuss payment of the wall". 

Pe√±a Nieto: "I made it clear that Mexico will not pay for the wall".

Hmmm....

status_message:
My friend Bob shared this with me. His daughter, Veronika, was shot and killed during the 2014 mass shooting at UC Santa Barbara. His story is a heart-wrenching reminder of the effects of gun violence and why Proposition 63 is so important. Hope you will read: 

My daughter Veronika used to surprise me with lunch at work so we could eat together. How many high school kids want to spend more time with their parents?
 
Since May 23, 2014, the day my 19-year-old daughter was shot and killed in the mass shooting in Isla Vista, there hasn‚Äôt been a day when I wouldn‚Äôt give anything to eat lunch with her again. To hear about her last math test, her next cross-country meet ‚Äì to hear her laugh.
 
I know nothing I do now will change the fact that my daughter‚Äôs life was taken by a man who should never have had a gun on the day that he murdered six innocent people. Nothing will make my daughter show up outside my office door again. 
 
No parent should ever have to wonder what kind of amazing things their child would‚Äôve done or how they would‚Äôve grown up, if given the time. The headlines may disappear the next day, but the families and loved ones who are left behind to deal with the terrible loss don't forget. We cannot forget, and we cannot wait for another terrible reminder of what can happen when the wrong person has a gun.
 
We cannot just keep watching the NRA tighten its grip on Congress, and politicians do nothing while families like mine get ripped apart. We‚Äôve got to educate our fellow Californians about Safety for All and pass Prop. 63 this November. Lives depend on it.
Warning: these letters truly are "heart-melting". Love that my daughters will grow up knowing that they can do anything, including running for President of the United States!
link_name: 16 Heart-Melting Letters to Hillary Clinton From Girls Who Just Want to See a Woman in the White House

status_message:
One of the things I really value about social media is the ability to engage in dialogue with people I may never get the opportunity to meet. One of my followers and supporters wrote the below after I posted about Trump's candidacy -- thought I'd share with you all. Really impactful words. Thank you, Cheryl, for engaging. 

"Vote carefully for the future. 

You know, unexpected things happen in life all the time. 

If my loved ones are victims of rape and get pregnant, I don't want to be the one who advocated the ban for abortion. 

If my loved ones decide to live with partners of the same sex, I don't want to be the one who denied them equal rights, shamed and discriminated against them for their sexuality. 

If my loved ones struggle to break the glass ceiling that is holding them back at work, I don't want to be the one who voted for the party who do not see women as equals and deserving of equal pay. 

If my loved ones marry into another faith and converts, I don't want to be the one who called for the discrimination of all other religions except my own. 

If anything untoward happens to my loved ones during a gun crime, I don't want to be the person who voted against gun control. 

I will fight because you never know what will happen tomorrow. 
I hope you never have to be the one obstructing the happiness of your loved ones in the future.

I hope you will vote for all of our futures."

Jen and I visited the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library this weekend where a piece of the Berlin Wall was on display. For me, this piece of the Berlin Wall - which fell 27 years ago - represents the power of diplomacy to transform our world - and a reminder of what is possible when our nation engages in dialogue not just with our friends, but with our adversaries as well. I hope we continue to tear down walls in our society and work toward inclusiveness and equality for all.

status_message:
"We‚Äôre used to war as metaphor: the war on poverty, the war on drugs, the war on cancer. Usually this is just a rhetorical device, a way of saying, ‚ÄúWe need to focus our attention and marshal our forces to fix something we don‚Äôt like.‚Äù But this is no metaphor. By most of the ways we measure wars, climate change is the real deal: Carbon and methane are seizing physical territory, sowing havoc and panic, racking up casualties, and even destabilizing governments. (Over the past few years, record-setting droughts have helped undermine the brutal strongman of Syria and fuel the rise of Boko Haram in Nigeria.) 

It‚Äôs not that global warming is like a world war. It is a world war. Its first victims, ironically, are those who have done the least to cause the crisis. But it‚Äôs a world war aimed at us all. And if we lose, we will be as decimated and helpless as the losers in every conflict--except that this time, there will be no winners, and no end to the planetwide occupation that follows."

An extraordinary read last week from Bill McKibben.  We must redefine our national and global approach to climate change.  This is a war in which pacifism is not an option.
link_name: We Need to Literally Declare War on Climate Change

status_message:
I need to get something off my chest here. I've heard too many people this week say Trump is good news because it means certain victory for Democrats this election.

He‚Äôs running with an ‚ÄúR‚Äù next to his name, but what Donald Trump has done this election cycle -- the anger and bigotry he has fueled, the violence he‚Äôs incited -- is not a problem just for the Republicans to deal with.

What Trump is saying and doing is downright bad for our country, it‚Äôs bad for our reputation abroad, and it‚Äôs bad for our democracy. It makes me sick he‚Äôs gotten this far in the process.

This election isn‚Äôt about choosing between two people or even between two parties. This is about choosing a future where we tear down walls and barriers, not build new ones. It‚Äôs about rejecting race-baiting, fearmongering and cynical bigotry.

Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôm getting at: I don't want to win this election because the other guy is an unhinged, racist con man (which he is). I want to win because we stood together behind our ideas and defended our deepest values.

I refuse to watch my kids grow up in a world where self-serving, power-hungry frauds like Trump win. When we look back on this election 20 years from now, I want them to see that we refused to let such a candidate win -- that we stood up for what our country is truly about: life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness. That all are created equal. That America is an engine of job creation and creativity, and that we‚Äôve succeeded not just through innovation but through acceptance. Pro-worker. Pro-women. Pro-environment. Pro-immigrant. Pro-gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender.

I want this to be the start of a conversation, so feel free to reply here. Appreciate hearing what‚Äôs on your mind.

MYTH: Prop 63 violates the Second Amendment.

THE FACTS: Nothing in Prop 63 violates the Second Amendment. The Supreme Court has held that the Second Amendment protects the right of law-abiding, responsible citizens to own a handgun in the home for self-defense. Courts have overwhelmingly upheld a wide variety of federal, state, and local laws that, like Prop 63, seek to prevent dangerous people from accessing guns and ammunition, keep especially dangerous military-style weaponry off our streets, and place conditions on the sale of these lethal products.
Happy 70th President Bill Clinton! Grateful for your leadership and your friendship.  Here‚Äôs to many more years of you pointing out the value of ‚Äúarithmetic!‚Äù
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
He's in shock. Yes, from the bomb, but also because he was asleep when that bomb hit. There is no time more innocent then when a child is woken up or wakes up.  Whenever I have a long day out with my kids and they've been extra difficult, I'll admit that when they fall asleep in the back seat, it's a welcome moment of quiet. But when we arrive home and I have to scoop them up and take them to their beds, no matter what they've done that day, I will have forgotten about it because at that moment they are warm, sweet, and vulnerable. 

Omran Daqneesh may have been exposed to war and lost some of his innocence already, but that didn't matter, nothing could have prepared him for what he faced last night.  Grown men and women are traumatized by war, imagine what a five-year-old feels. Children who face the trauma of war or violence of any kind will admit that they have nightmares, but they also say that sleep, dreaming offers them a respite they so desperately need.  And that's what makes Omran's situation even more heartbreaking, he wasn't even aware of what was about to happen, he wasn't awoken by the sound of his mother or father's voice or the sun shining through his window, he was awoken by the sound of war.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: "Horrific mass shootings ‚Äî like the recent massacres in Dallas and Orlando ‚Äî continue to ravage America with sickening regularity, leaving many wondering what can be done to stop the bloodshed. Californians who feel helpless about our nation‚Äôs epidemic of gun violence will have a clear opportunity to take action, however, by voting in November for Proposition 63 ‚Äî the Safety for All Act ‚Äî a ballot initiative to close several deadly loopholes in our state‚Äôs gun laws." - Juliet A. Leftwich, Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence
link_name: Gun measure brings safety for all

status_message:
MYTH: We don‚Äôt need new gun safety laws‚Äîwe should just enforce the laws we have.

THE FACTS: Prop 63 will help enforce existing laws by closing dangerous loopholes in those laws. For example, while California makes it illegal for felons and violent criminals to have ammunition, it doesn‚Äôt require them to pass a background check to buy it. And while California requires dangerous criminals to get rid of their firearms after they‚Äôre convicted, it doesn‚Äôt require them to provide proof that they did so. Prop 63 will close these dangerous loopholes to improve enforcement of our gun laws.
Who wore it better --- Me or the cast of The Sound of Music? Lederhosen never go out of style! #TBT
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
It's very important to be aware of the lies that the gun lobby and those opposed to Prop. 63 (on the CA ballot in November) are putting out there. I'm going to be posting 10 common myths v. facts to breakdown the opposition's lies and arguments with real data and truth -- really hope you will share these as we work together to end gun violence in California.

Myth #1: Gun safety laws like Prop 63 won‚Äôt work because criminals won‚Äôt follow them.

THE FACTS: The reality is that smart gun laws save lives and do not rely on criminals‚Äô compliance. Nationally, background checks have blocked nearly 2.5 million convicted felons, domestic abusers, and dangerously mentally ill people from illegally acquiring guns. Studies also show that states with stronger gun safety laws have much lower rates of gun violence. Over the last 2 decades, California has led the nation in strengthening its gun laws and, as a result, our state has cut its gun death rate by nearly 60%, twice as much as the other states. But we have more work to do. Prop 63 includes major reforms to proactively keep criminals from getting and using deadly weapons and to help law enforcement hold them accountable when they do.
Spot on.
link_name: Timeline Photos

"Michael R. Bloomberg, who bypassed his own run for the presidency this election cycle, will endorse Hillary Clinton in a prime-time address at the Democratic convention and make the case for Mrs. Clinton as the best choice for moderate voters in 2016, an adviser to Mr. Bloomberg said.

The news is an unexpected move from Mr. Bloomberg, who has not been a member of the Democratic Party since 2000; was elected the mayor of New York City as a Republican; and later became an independent.

But it reflects Mr. Bloomberg‚Äôs increasing dismay about the rise of Donald J. Trump and a determination to see that the Republican nominee is defeated."
link_name: Dismayed by Donald Trump, Michael Bloomberg Will Endorse Hillary Clinton

status_message:
This is one of the most important looks into Trump and his racism that I've read. Are you one of those people who wonders if Trump's demagoguery/racism is an act to get attention and votes? It's not. Nicholas Kristof lays out 40 years of proof. 

"Another revealing moment came in 1989, when New York City was convulsed by the ‚ÄúCentral Park jogger‚Äù case, a rape and beating of a young white woman. Five black and Latino teenagers were arrested.  Trump stepped in, denounced Mayor Ed Koch‚Äôs call for peace and bought full-page newspaper ads calling for the death penalty. The five teenagers spent years in prison before being exonerated. In retrospect, they suffered a modern version of a lynching, and Trump played a part in whipping up the crowds."
link_name: Is Donald Trump a Racist?

status_message:
Can you imagine what it feels like to put on a uniform every day and know that there's a chance that you may not come home? I can't.  No one truly knows what it's like unless they've served in law enforcement. We are lucky enough, as a nation, that over one million men and women are willing to put on their uniform and head to work every day knowing full well that they may not come home that night or that they may end up injured in the hospital. 

A vast majority of these brave men and women do their jobs well and with integrity.  They do their jobs for a salary that doesn't even begin to match the sacrifice that they and their families make. If you talk to police officers, most of them will say they aren't in law enforcement because they're just looking for employment, they could do any number of jobs and make more money and not risk their lives in the process. They're in law enforcement because they want to keep their communities safe, they want to help people. 

The officers killed and injured in Baton Rouge today did not incite violence, they walked into it. And even though they are thousands of miles from my family and me, I owe them and their loved ones more than just my thoughts, I owe them a debt of gratitude because our safety can't be compartmentalized.  By keeping Baton Rouge safe, they kept my family and me safe.  We can't just be concerned that our neighborhood is safe or that our city is safe, we have to want safety for everyone in America, no matter who they are, what they look like or where they live.

status_message:
Holocaust survivor. Nobel Peace Prize winner. Elie Wiesel is proof that you don't need formal authority to change the world, all you need is the moral authority. Sadly, he passed away today at 87. After facing the horror of Nazi concentration camps, after losing his father, his mother and his younger sister, Mr. Wiesel had every reason to give up, but he didn't. Instead of standing down, he spent his entire life fighting for human rights around the world.  If you haven't read his extraordinary memoir, Night, I hope you will. 

"There may be times when we are powerless to prevent injustice, but there must never be a time when we fail to protest."  

- Elie Wiesel

status_message:
#BoycottCinemark

This weekend many of you will go to the movies with your families and friends. When deciding which theater to go to, I hope you'll stay away from Cinemark and any of the theaters it owns (cinemark.com). 

The Cinemark theater in Aurora, Colorado was the site of one of the worst mass shootings in our history, 12 people were killed and 70 were injured. 

In the aftermath of the shooting, some of the victims chose to sue Cinemark for what they deemed to be various security loopholes in the theater. In May, a jury decided that Cinemark was not liable for damages.  I'm not going to get into whether or not their lawsuits had merit -- it's what Cinemark elected to do after they won that has me angry. 

Under Colorado law -- and this is the case in many states -- if a person files suit and loses, they are often on the hook for the attorney's fees of the opposing side. Cinemark, a company with a net operating income of over $200 million a year has elected to exercise their right to recover and is demanding $700,000 from two dozen survivors and some of the parents who lost their kids in the shooting. 

I'm a pro-business Democrat (I own over a dozen small businesses myself) but capitalism without empathy is not the American way -- we are better than this. Cinemark may have the right to recover attorney fees but why would they want to re-victimize over two dozen people who have faced the horror of gun violence. Some of the injured victims in this case, have had to have multiple surgeries...the parents, in this case, have lost their children. 

Cinemark should have taken its victory and moved on -- to demand $700,000 from people who can least afford it is unconscionable. 

I have attached the audio from a radio interview today where I discussed the boycott. 

#BoycottCinemark
link_name: Audio Only: #BoycottCinemark

status_message:
On this day 23 years ago, a mass shooting at a law firm in downtown San Francisco ended with 8 dead and 6 wounded. The shooting left the victims' families and loved ones devastated, and sent shockwaves through the Bay Area‚Äôs community.

Within days, a group of local attorneys responded by forming the Legal Community Against Violence, now known as the Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence.  Unwilling to stand by, they mobilized the Bay Area legal community to step up and help stop the violence.  23 years later, California has lead the way with commonsense gun reforms that have resulted in a dramatic decrease in gun deaths‚Äîa 56% drop over two decades, statewide.

Last fall, the Law Center and I came together to co-author the Safety for All Act, which will be on the CA November ballot. The folks at the Law Center know that we are not innocent bystanders - we can and must take action. Will you join us? We believe we can make a difference in CA, but we need your help.  

www.safetyforall.com
link_name: Safety for All

status_message: In the past 72 hours...93 people have died and 205 people have been injured due to gun violence in America. This does not include Orlando.

Twelve years ago, when I ordered the San Francisco city clerk to give same-sex couples marriage licenses, I was filled with a sense of hope ‚Äì a hope that together we could produce change and create a sense of acceptance and openness for every American, no matter what his or her sexual orientation might be. I watched as couples across the nation were given the opportunity to express their love for one another and the happiness it brought to communities across our state and country.

Then yesterday morning came. I woke to see 49 people of the LGBT community had been shot and killed by a man filled with hatred, threatened by the openness and diversity we have worked so hard to embed in our culture and communities.

I am heartbroken. I am outraged. 

It makes me sick to even begin discussing politics in the immediate aftermath of such a massacre ‚Äì but to tell you the truth, I‚Äôve heard too many on the right labeling what happened at Pulse an act of Islamic terrorism and forgetting to mention the issues of homophobia, transphobia and gun rights that lie at the center of this massacre and run rampant through our national discourse.

Yesterday as President Obama addressed our nation for the 15th time on gun violence, he said, "This massacre is a further reminder of how easy it is for someone to get their hands on a weapon that lets them shoot people in a school, or in a house of worship, or a movie theater, or in a nightclub. And we have to decide if that's the kind of country we want to be. And to actively do nothing is a decision as well.‚Äù

I‚Äôve made my decision. I‚Äôm taking action to keep guns and ammo out of the hands of violent, dangerous, hateful people. That‚Äôs what our Safety for All initiative is all about and why it‚Äôs so important that we all get behind it. Lives depend on it.

 It‚Äôs time to make decisions, take action and save lives. America has too many guns and too much bigotry. The result is the massacre in Orlando. I lament for the families, loved ones and all those touched by this terrible crime. But, more importantly, I‚Äôm committed to taking action.

Click here to learn more and to donate: www.safetyforall.com
Brenda Marquez McCool....Mom of eleven kids....Cancer survivor (twice).....She loved to dance.... #6of49 #PulseOrlando #WeSpeakYourName

But we need to raise the money to fight the NRA -- will you please help? We need your help. Click here to make a contribution and help us get the word out: http://bit.ly/1hKGJz6

I hope you'll watch and share my buddy Andy Cohen's touching statement on the Pulse nightclub tragedy from his show Watch What Happens Live .

"This month is Pride month for the LGBT community, and as we have been so brutally reminded today, it‚Äôs about more than parties and parades ‚Äî it is also a celebration of our civil rights. There are people who wish that we do not exist but we do. And it is with a great deal of pride that this gay American is going to try to put a smile on your face at the end of a sad day, in this clubhouse where everyone is welcome and everyone is loved."
link_name: Andy Cohen's Touching Statement About LGBT Pride
